cip.render

Class FrameLoader

  • java.lang.Object
    • cip.render.FrameLoader

  • public class FrameLoader
extends java.lang.Object
    This is a frame loader for an XML description of a frame. The description includes the frame rendering options plus a description of the frame (lights, cameras, geometry). The general form of the XML scene description file is a root RenderFrame node with rendering specific attributes such as default resolution, oversampling, which camera to use, dimmer, etc.; and has as children nodes the description of the geometry and lights in the scene. The phylosophy is to specify all of the contained geometry, lights, cameras, materials, etc. as dynamically loaded objects. By this, we mean that the node describing some object specifies the class that should be instantiated to handle the object, and the contents of the node will be specific to that node. All dynamic nodes are loaded by the DynXmlObjLoader. The FrameLoader queries the interfaces of the loaded objects to determine object capabilities and how they should be used in the scene.

    The general form of the XML file for a rendered frame is: 

         <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

     <RenderedFrame frameAttributes>
         <LibraryObjects>
    
             <!-- These objects are loaded, but not used in the scene unless references by scene objects -->
             <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="classname"
                                      name="objectName">
                   .
                 class specific nodes and attributes
                   .
             </DynamicallyLoadedObject>
               .
               .
         </LibraryObjects>

         <!-- These objects are the scene objects -->
         <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="classname"
                                  name="objectName">
               .
             class specific nodes and attributes
               .
         </DynamicallyLoadedObject>
         <GeometryByRef name="geometrytName"/>
         <LightByRef name="lightName"/>
           .
           .
     </RenderedFrame>
    where the frameAttributes are:
    dimmer The light source global dimmer. This is normally between 0 and 1 and would be specified as: 

         dimmer="0.5"
    The default value is 1.0 if this attribute has not been specified.
    pixelSamples

    The number of sample points per pixel - actually the size of one side of the sampling grid in a a pixel. For example: 1 is a 1x1 sampling grid or 1 sample per pixel, 2 is a 2x2 sampling grid or 4 samples per pixel, 3 is a 3x3 sampling grid or 9 samples per pixel. The default is 1 if pixelSamples is not specified.

    Processing this attribute is optional and dependent on the implementation of IRenderScene used to render the scene.

    pixelKernel

    The size of the pixel sampling kernel. This is normally either 1 or 2 where 1 means all the samples in a pixel contribute only to that pixel, while 2 means that a pixel accumulates contributions from all on the nieghboring pixels.

    Processing this attribute is optional and dependent on the implementation of IRenderScene used to render the scene.

    and the elements that can be used within the RenderFrame element are:
    LibraryObjects Within this element specify library geometry, lights, and materials that will be referenced by name when other objects are loaded. Library objects are not loaded into the scene unless they are referenced within the scene either directly using the GeometryByRef or LightByRef element tags.
    DynamicallyLoadedObject These are dynamically loaded objects (see DynXmlObjLoader) that are either geometry implement the IDynXmlObject interface for loading from an XML file, the INamedObject for object naming and referencing, and at least one of the following interfaces so that it can do something in the context of a ray tracer:

    Implements IRtBackground so that it can act as a background.

    Implements IRtCamera so that it can act as a camera.

    Implements IRtGeometry so that it can act as a geometry.

    Implements IRtLight so that it can act as a light source.

    Implements IRtMaterial so that it can act as a material.
    GeometryByRef A reference to a library or previously loaded geometry. This will establish a reference to the first instance of that geometry that was loaded - whether as a library object or within the scene.
    LightByRef A reference to a library or previously loaded light. This will establish a reference to the first instance of that light that was loaded - whether as a library object or within the scene.
    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    DynXmlObjLoader

      • FrameLoader

        public FrameLoader(java.lang.String strXmlFile)
            throws java.lang.Exception
        Creates a new instance of FrameLoader which is initialized to the described scene.
        Parameters:
        strXmlFile - The name of the scene description file. See class notes for format information.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - An exception is thrown if the scene could not be loaded.

    • Method Detail

      • tryParseMaterial

        public static IRtMaterial tryParseMaterial(@NotNull
                                           @NotNull org.w3c.dom.Element element,
                                           @Nullable
                                           @Nullable java.util.LinkedList refObjectList,
                                           @NotNull
                                           @NotNull java.lang.String strObjType,
                                           @NotNull
                                           @NotNull java.lang.String strObjName)
                                    throws DynXmlObjParseException
        A method that can be called by geometry and texture loaders to try to parse a material or a reference to a material.
        Parameters:
        element - (not null, readonly) The XML element this methods will try to parse as a material.
        refObjectList - (nullable, readonly) The reference object list.
        strObjType - (not null) The calling object type, to be used in error messages.
        strObjName - (not null) The calling object name in the scene description file, to be used in error messages.
        Returns:
        Returns null if this element is NOT a dynamically loaded material or material reference.
        Throws:
        DynXmlObjParseException - Thrown if an in-line material has a parsing error or if a material reference cannot be found in the reference object list.

      • initSampling

        public void initSampling(int nSample,
                         float[] f1dSample,
                         float[] f1dRandom,
                         Point2f[] pt2dSample,
                         Point2f[] pt2dRandom,
                         Point3f[] pt3dSample,
                         Point3f[] pt3dRandom)
        Initialize all the loaded objects in the scene for sampling or oversampling. This function should be called between the time the frame is loaded and when you start to get the loaded elements from the frame. It loops through all the loaded elements and calls the initSampling function for the element,
        Parameters:
        nSample - (readonly) The number of sub-samples (over-samples) per pixel in x and y; i.e. 3 means a 3x3 sampling grid.
        f1dSample - The 1d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling linear phenomena.
        f1dRandom - The 1d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.
        pt2dSample - The 2d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling area phenomena.
        pt2dRandom - The 2d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.
        pt3dSample - The 3d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling volume phenomena.
        pt3dRandom - The 3d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.

      • getCamera

        public IRtCamera getCamera()
        Return the camera. If a camera is not specified in the scene description file, this defaults to a front view through a PinHole camera. If more than one camera is specified in the scene description, the first encountered camera is the one that is returned here.
        Returns:
        Returns the interface to the camera.

      • getBackground

        public IRtBackground getBackground()
        Return the background. If a background is not specified in the scene description file, this defaults to a black ConstantColour background. If more than one background is specified in the scene description, the first encountered background is the one that is returned here.
        Returns:
        Returns the interface to the background.

      • getGeometryHierarchy

        public java.util.LinkedList<IRtGeometry> getGeometryHierarchy()
        Return a linked list of all the first-level geometries in the scene. Any groups are preserved as groups, so the hierarchy of the scene description is maintained.
        Returns:
        Returns the hierarchical list of geometries in the scene.

      • getGeometryFlat

        public java.util.LinkedList<IRtGeometry> getGeometryFlat()
        Returns a flatted list of geometries in the scene. All groups are expanded and the transformations accumulated and applied to individual geometry. While each geometry returned will have a sngle leaf node (the actual geometry) and the transformations will be aggregated into a single XfmGeometry if possible.
        Returns:
        Returns the flatted list of geometries in the scene.

      • getLights

        public java.util.LinkedList<IRtLight> getLights()
        Returns a flattened list of lights in the scene.
        Returns:
        Returns the flattened list of lights in the scene.

      • getDimmer

        public float getDimmer()
        Returns the global dimmer. The global dimmer defaults to 1.0 if not specified in the scene description.
        Returns:
        Returns the global dimmer.

      • getSamplesPerPixel

        public int getSamplesPerPixel()
        Returns the samples-per-pixel that should be used for rendering. The default is 1 sample per pixel if not specified in the scene description. The interpretation is left to the rendering implementation using the loader, but, generally: a value of 1 means 1 sample per pixel; a value or 2 means a 2x2 sampling grid or 4 samples per pixel; a value of 3 menas a 3x3 sampling grid or 9 samples per pivel, etc.
        Returns:
        Returns the target samples per pixel.

      • getSampleKernel

        public int getSampleKernel()
        Returns the size of the filter kernel. The default is 1 pixel if not specified in the scene description. A 1 pixel kernel means only the samples within the pixel are used to compute the pixel colour. A 2 pixel kernel generally means the sampling extends into the adjacent pixels using a weighted sampling - though this is dependent on renderer implementation.
        Returns:
        Returns the sample kernel.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        This main is for the express purpose of testing the loader. It reads an XML scene description then writes it back out from the loaded description. This tests both the scene loading at a high level, and the IDynXmlObject implementation at an object level. In the current implementation of the test, there is no automatic comparison of the input and output for equivalence. This must be done by visual inspection of the output files.

        Note: What comes out will probably not be a literal copy of what went in. There is no processing on output to consolidate multiply used objects into reference objects, and, no reference objects are written out. The ONLY thing written out is a fully specified description of the environment as if all objects in the environment are unique instances.

        Usage:

        Parameters:
        args - The arguments
